info.name: GD2-1-1_hello_world
info.extended_description: This transformation generates 10 rows with the message Hello World.

notepad.note:
This transformation generates rows, 'hello world'. Illustrates some of the key features:
Step1: Generate Rows Limit: 10 rows
Name: message Type: String Value: hello world
click: Preview
Step2: Dummy
Guided Demonstration: 2-1-1 Hello World
Changing the format from String to Integer results in an error.
Guided Demonstration: 2-1-2 Hello World (Logging)
Change the Data type from String to Integer.

This transformation illustrates CSV File input step to read the sales_data.csv file.
Step1: CSV File input - Read Sales Data Browse for the ..\samples\transformations\files\sales_data.csv Delimiter: , Select: Lazy conversion & Head row present Click: Get fields Click: Preview
Step2: Select values Select the Meta-data tab: Click: Get fields to change Change the format of the ORDERDATE to create errors:
Type: Format: Date yyyy/MM/dd This will cause errors..!
Step3: Text File Output - Correct Used to Preview correct data
Step4: Text File Output - Error Configure the hop for error logging
Guided Demonstration: 2-2-1 Metadata Conversion

Remember to configure for errors: Double click on Hop ..
Select Copy for record distribution
Correct format: MM/dd/yyyy

The transformation is used to illustrate 'Visual data Experience'
There are two options: Run and Inspect - will execute the transformation and allow data inspection. Inspect - uses cached data. If none exisits then will Execute the Transformation.
Guided Demonstration: 2-3-1 Visual Data Experience

info.extended_description: This transformation generates 10 rows with the message Hello World.

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration: 2-4-1 Hello World

info.name: GD3-1-1_read_text
info.extended_description: The workflow loads an unstructured list of orders, flattens field1 into 4 stream fields: - productline - customer - status - order_value Further stream fields are added based onthe capture group constructs that resolve order_status & order_date. Repeating text is removed from the order_value stream field, before the order_value is formatted: $#.00

parameter.name: ORDERS_FILENAME
parameter.default_value: C:\Users\joreilly\Dropbox\EMEA Training\PDI ILT Course\Module 3 - Datasources\Lesson 1 - Working with Files\Demo 3-1-1 - Read Text File\orders.txt

notepad.note: This guided demonstration illustrates the options available in the Text File Input step. The data in the text file is flattened, parsed to capture groups, before the price is defined with the data type: Number.
Guided Demonstration: 3-1-1 Text File Input
- read a list of orders.
The RegEx expression creates 2 capture groups: order_status: (Delivered | Returned) order_date: (.+)
General Guidelines: - separator: TAB - there's a white space after Order Value:

info.name: GD3-1-2_ write_text
info.extended_description: This trasformation shows how to generate a file.

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration: 3-1-2 Write Text File Output

This guided demonstration illustrates how to write a file. The first part of the transformation, defines the 'head':
Customer name: ------------------------------------ Please answer the questions below:
Which is then apended to the 'body', which adds the questions..
1. How many employees currently in your organisation? 2. Which ETL tool do you currently use? 3. What would you do if you had a magic wand?
Guided Demonstration: 3-1-3 Write Excel File
This guided demonstration creates an Excel workbook based on a template that is populated from several Excel spreadsheets, with text files as their datasource.
Adds Year to SourceData sheet, in the template.xlsx
Adds Sales Data to SourceData sheet, in template.xlsx
Adds expenses to SourceData, in template.xlsx
Guided Demonstration: 3-1-4 Read XML
A simple example of reading an xml file
Reading xml from a URL
Read Json file and extract portions data out of structure.
Guided Demonstration: 3-1-5 Read JSON
Guided Demonstration: 3-2-1 Database Connection

Connection to the Hypersonic Steel Wheels sample database.
Connection Nmae: Sampledata Connection Type: Hypersonic Host Name: localhost Database Name: SampleData Port Number: 9001 User Name: pentaho_admin Password: password
1. Select the View tab. 2. Expand: Database Connections. 3. Right mouse click on Sampledata. 4. Select Share.
Guided Demonstration: 3-2-2 Write to a Database
Simple transformation that writes the sales_data.csv to a table
Required for GD 4-1-2 Merged Rows (diff) Database
Guided Demonstration: 3-2-3 Reading from a Database
Steel Wheels wish to produce a report, tracking the delivery status of each order.
Connect to the ORDERS table and return just those orders that have shipped.
Calculate the 'delivery time' = 'Shipped date' - 'Required date'.
Set the delivery criteria: Early = shipped more than 2 days before the 'Required date'. On Time = shipped within 2 days of the 'Required date'. Late = shipped after the 'Required date'.
Sort the 'delivery status'.
Select the following fields: Delivery Ordernumber Required Date (Format MM/dd/yyyy) Shipped Date (Format MM/dd/yyyy)

step.name: Table input
step.sql: SELECT ORDERNUMBER , ORDERDATE , REQUIREDDATE , SHIPPEDDATE , STATUS , COMMENTS , CUSTOMERNUMBER FROM ORDERS WHERE STATUS = 'Shipped'

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 3-2-3: Reading from a Database Table
Steel Wheels wish to launch a new marketing campaign, aimed at those customers who haven't placed an order in the last 30 days.
Connect to the stg_sales_data table. Modify the SQL to return 'Shipped' orders.
Format the ORDERDATE MM/dd/yyyy
Sort the: Customername Orderdate
Analytic Query retrieves the value of a stream field either FORWARD or BACKWARD based on the Group field and offset (N value).
Calculate days elapsed since previous order
Set Action Flags
Switch based on the value in the Action Flag field

step.name: stg sales data
step.sql: SELECT ORDERNUMBER , SALES , ORDERDATE , STATUS , CUSTOMERNAME , PHONE , CONTACTLASTNAME , CONTACTFIRSTNAME FROM STG_SALES_DATA WHERE STATUS = 'Shipped'

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration: 3-2-4 Employee Update

In this demonstration the EMPLOYEE table is just updated.
Inspect the EMPLOYEE Table and compare the records against the employee_update.txt

The stream fields are mapped to the database table by ensuring: EMPLOYEE_NUMBER = EMPLOYEENUMBER
Ensure all the Field mappings are correct
Guided Demonstration: 3-2-5 Employee Insert / Update

In this demonstration the EMPLOYEE table is updated and new records are inserted.
Inspect the EMPLOYEE Table and compare the records against the employee.txt

The stream fields are mapped to the database table by ensuring: EMPLOYEE_NUMBER = EMPLOYEENUMBER
Ensure all the Field mappings are correct
Guided Demonstration: 3-2-6 Dimension Lookup / Update (Type I & II)

This demonstration illustrates the behaviour of the 2 step modes:
Dimension Update / Insert - records are updated or inserted into the table (Type I) Dimension Lookup - current records are llooked up and compared with stream field. If the record exists in the stream field, but not in the database table, then its held in cache and assigned TK0. (Type I)
For Type II SCDs the table inserts a record (notes a change in the Stream Datefield), version, updating the records with required date range.
Lists the Productline. Could have used a Lookup.
Retrieves the value for the ${min_quantityordered}. 50 Set in the Transformation Properties > Parameters.
Maps (sets Keys) the QUANTITYORDERED database field to the <= min_quantityordered stream field, as well as the PRODUCTLINE. Deletes the relevant records in the STG_SALES_DATA table.
Guided Demonstration 3-2-7: Delete

file.name: C:\Pentaho Training\DI 1000\Module 3 - Datasources\Lesson 2 - Working with Databases\Demo 3-2-8 - Deleting Records\productline.txt

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration: 3-2-8 Parameters
This demonstration illustrates the different options for passing parameters.

step.name: Steel Wheels Products 1
step.sql: SELECT PRODUCTLINE , PRODUCTSCALE , PRODUCTCODE , PRODUCTNAME FROM PRODUCTS WHERE PRODUCTLINE = ? AND PRODUCTSCALE = ?

step.name: Steel Wheels Products 2
step.sql: SELECT PRODUCTLINE , PRODUCTSCALE , PRODUCTCODE , PRODUCTNAME FROM PRODUCTS WHERE PRODUCTLINE = ? AND PRODUCTSCALE = ?

step.name: Steel Wheels Products 3
step.sql: SELECT PRODUCTLINE , PRODUCTSCALE , PRODUCTCODE , PRODUCTNAME FROM PRODUCTS WHERE PRODUCTLINE = ? AND PRODUCTSCALE = ?

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration: 3-2-8 Parameter

Steel Wheels wish to produce a report, tracking the delivery status of each order.
The SQL script has been modifed: ${STATUS} variable is set to 'Shipped' in the Transformation Properties / Parameters tab.

step.name: Table input
step.sql: SELECT ORDERNUMBER , ORDERDATE , REQUIREDDATE , SHIPPEDDATE , STATUS , COMMENTS , CUSTOMERNUMBER FROM ORDERS WHERE STATUS='${STATUS}'

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 4-1-1: Merge Streams
When you merge rows, its essential that the two streams have the same structure and layout.
Add PRODUCTDESCRIPTION field to the stream.
The text file has to have the same layout as orders to ensure the merge is successful.

attribute.value: {"namespace":"pentaho","id":"Kettle Data Service","name":"Kettle Data Service","description":"The elements describing data services based upon transformation output","metaStoreName":null}

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 4-1-2: Merge Streams (diff) Database
If the Merge rows (diff) step is used in conjunction with the Synchronize after merge, then based on the value of the flag, the database can be updated.
Set the database operations in the Advanced tab:

step.name: STG_ORDERS_MERGED
step.sql: SELECT PRODUCTCODE , PRODUCTNAME , PRODUCTLINE , PRODUCTSCALE , PRODUCTVENDOR , PRODUCTDESCRIPTION FROM STG_ORDERS_MERGED ORDER BY PRODUCTCODE

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 4-1-2: Merge Streams (diff)
The streams are mergred and the difference 'flagged' as:

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 4-2-2: Merge Join
Solves the problem of merge rows.. GD4-1-1 With a 'join' you dont have to ensure that each data stream has the same structure / layout.

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 4-2-2: Merge Join
Simple merge join demonstration.
Guided Demonstration 4-2-3: Database Joins
A Database Join enables a query to be run against the table based on the fields.

Parameters:
Prod: Aston Martin Ford Falcon Corvette
max_price: 100

Condition BUYPRICE was less than 90 and the column PRODUCTNAME contained %Aston Martin% returns values for: PRODUCTNAME, PRODUCTSCALE
BUYPRICE was less than 70 and the column PRODUCTNAME contained %Ford Falcon% returns null values for: PRODUCTNAME, PRODUCTSCALE

step.name: Database join
step.sql: SELECT PRODUCTNAME , PRODUCTSCALE , BUYPRICE FROM PRODUCTS WHERE PRODUCTNAME LIKE concat('%',?,'%') AND BUYPRICE < ?

notepad.note: Guided Demonstration 4-3-1: Database Lookup

Parameters:
Prod: Aston Martin max_price: 90 Ford Falcon max_price: 70 Corvette max_price: 70
The Database lookup step allows you to look for values in a database table.

step.name: Write to log
step.logmessage: ================================== no productname match at that price

notepad.note: Simple calculation
Applying Rules: IF( Logical Condition [ ; [ Any IfTrue ] [ ; [ Any IfFalse ] ] ] )
Guided Demonstration 4-4-2: Formula
The Formula step isnt really scripting, but does allow you to define complex formulae around: - Operators - Date / Time - Information - Logical - Mathematical - Text functions.
